# Part 2: A task {data-background=https://giphy.com/embed/gH85KtY9fX2yd9eG4F data-background-size=cover}

## Details

1. Download this file from GitHub: https://is.gd/IPCC2022
2. There are 62 pages, so run `sample(1:62, 1)` (`random.choice(range(1, 62)`) in python).  Then count the number of references and do `sample(1:n_ref, 1)` to pick a random paper and copy the DOI (must start with 10.)
3. Search for the term `data`, note down the number of times it is mentioned 
4. Search for `code`, note down the number of times it is mentioned 
5. Search for `http` - see if there is code or data linked to the article that can be downloaded
6. Fill in the Google form https://is.gd/IPCCform

## Some overall lessons I learnt

- If you want lots of citations write open-source software and get feedback from users
- Get users or non-expert collaborators to help write the instruction manual
- Keep (at least the first paper) as simple as possible
- Use social media and answer queries as quickly as you can

# Part 3: 5 pieces of advice

# 1. You can't make your work completely reproducible

## 2. .. but try to make every piece of work you do as reproducible as possible via

1. Make it open access (pretty much compulsory these days)
2. Make it so that people (especially you) can re-create your graphs
3. Make it so that they can generalise your code

# 3. Aim to turn every paper you write into an R package and at least put it on GitHub or similar

# 4. Write better comments in your code (nobody writes good comments)

# 5. Don't walk away from your hard work if you want to reap the benefits from it, (and be brave about mistakes in your shared code)

## Some useful resources

1. [Writing R packages](https://r-pkgs.org)
2. [The BES guide to reproducibility]( https://www.britishecologicalsociety.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/guide-to-reproducible-code.pdf)
3. [GitHub](https://github.com) and [Github Large File Storage](https://git-lfs.github.com)
4. Defining good [folder structures]( https://github.com/ropensci/rrrpkg)

## The future!

	1. All journals requiring code/data that runs and reproduces the figures
	2. The ability to submit data (done) and the ability to submit code (Zenodo?)
	3. Automated reproducibility
	
## Summary

	1. Making your papers/code reproducible is to your advantage* (*if you're intending to pursue a career in academia)
	2. Learn the tools of the trade (e.g. R packages, Rmarkdown, GitHub) for reproducibility
	3. Make reproducibility a cornerstone of every paper you write
	4. Do you best and don't beat yourself up about not making everything reproducible
